Baghdad Company produces a single product. They have recently received the result of a market survey that indicates that they can increase the retail price of their product by 10% without losing customers or market share. All other costs will remain unchanged. If they enact the 10% price increase, what will be their new break-even point in units and dollars? Their most recent CVP analysis is: <image 1> 

A. 350 units and $34,647.65
B. 355 units and $35,647.65
C. 350 units and $35,647.65
D. 355 units and $34,647.65

To determine the new break-even point after a 10% price increase, we need to follow these steps:

1. Calculate the new sales price per unit.
2. Calculate the new contribution margin per unit.
3. Calculate the new break-even point in units and dollars.

### Step 1: Calculate the New Sales Price Per Unit
The current sales price per unit is $90. A 10% increase is calculated as follows:
\[ \text{New Sales Price} = \text{Current Sales Price} + (\text{Current Sales Price} \times 10\%) \]
\[ \text{New Sales Price} = 90 + ( (90 \times 0.10) \]
\[ \text{New Sales Price} = 90 + 9 \]
\[ \text{New Sales Price} = 99 \]

### Step 2: Calculate the New Contribution Margin Per Unit
The current contribution margin per unit is $50. Since the variable cost per unit remains the same, the new contribution margin per unit is:
\[ \text{New Contribution Margin} = \text{New Sales Price} - \text{Variable Cost Per Unit} \]
\[ \text{New Contribution Margin} = 99 - 40 \]
\[ \text{New Contribution Margin} = 59 \]

### Step 3: Calculate the New Break-Even Point in Units and Dollars
The new break-even point in units is calculated as:
\[ \text{New Break-Even Point ( (in units)} = \frac{\text{Fixed Costs}}{\text{New Contribution Margin Per Unit}} \]
\[ \text{New Break-Even Point ( (in units)} = \frac{20,650}{59} \]
\[ \text{New Break-Even Point ( (in units)} \approx 350 \]

The new break-even point in dollars is calculated as:
\[ \text{New Break-Even Point ( (in dollars)} = \text{New Break-Even Point ( (in units)} \times \text{New Sales Price Per Unit} \]
\[ \text{New Break-Even Point ( (in dollars)} = 350 \times 99 \]
\[ \text{New Break-Even Point ( in dollars)} = 34,650 \]

So, the new break-even point is approximately 350 units and $34,650.

The correct answer is:
A. 350 units and $34,647.65
